Description.val:
Underwater Explosive Ordnance Disposal (EOD) program supplies EOD and Maritime Expeditionary forces with the necessary allowance outfitting, and diving and diving-related equipment aligned to fulfill assigned missions that includes Expeditionary Mine Countermeasures (ExMCM), other Maritime Expeditionary missions, and Marine Mammal Systems (MMS) operations. Most equipment must have inherently low acoustic and magnetic signatures to support maritime operations in the vicinity of influence fired ordnance.  This funding supports outfitting the Navy's only comprehensive expeditionary mine countermeasures (ExMCM) capability in the fleet that can conduct full spectrum detect-to-engage expeditionary MCM missions. Specifically, the Underwater Explosive Ordnance Disposal (EOD) program supports EOD Groups, Units, and Detachments worldwide. 

The establishment of ExMCM Forces under the direction of Commander, US Fleet Forces Command has resulted in an increased inventory requirement for Underwater EOD systems and equipment, with a resultant requirement for re-aligned procurement and fielding priorities. The nature of the missions assigned to EOD and MCM forces under OPNAVINST 3501.97H, Required Operational Capabilities & Projected Operational Environments (ROC/POE), require an aggregated set of systems and equipment to perform the wide range of mine countermeasures, underwater detection, location, investigation, force protection, and neutralization tasks that comprise the mission set. The requirements for the procurement of each of these system suites are articulated in OPNAV approved requirements documents in accordance with DoD Directive 5000.2, SECNAVINST 5000.2E, and the JCIDS process as defined by CJSCINST 3170.01.

Naval Special Warfare (NSW) - FY 2018 initiates a service-common systems program for Naval Special Warfare's (NSW) Unmanned Undersea Vehicles (UUVs). Naval Special Warfare currently employs UUVs as an intelligence collection platform, building situational awareness of the Undersea Domain, and prior to conducting clandestine operations in support of the highest strategic objectives. UUVs are critical to NSW's undersea component, mission planning for anti-access and area denial (A2AD) environments, and the current fight against violent extremist organizations.  The use of open architecture, untethered platforms not only buys down risk to mission and force, but also provides the operational commander a diversified menu of employment options.

Justification.val:
FY 2018 funding is required to procure Underwater EOD program systems and equipment to outfit Expeditionary MCM Companies, EOD and Mobile Salvage units with hardware required to accomplish their OPNAV approved Required Operational Capability and Projected Operational Environments. This equipment will allow warfighters to detect, locate, investigate, neutralize and render safe unexploded ordnance including improvised explosive devices. The ExMCM capabilities being delivered under this program directly support the surge MCM capacity and capability outlined in the FY17 US Navy Mine Countermeasure report submitted to Congress under provisions of the FY16 National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) that will provide a more agile and cost effective warfighting capability through a modular and adaptive MCM force approach.

Additionally, FY2018 funding is required to procure product improvements needed for systems designed and first produced over 40 years ago, as well as the production engineering and integrated logistics support needed for all Expeditionary MCM Companies, EOD Units, and Expeditionary Salvage units. These systems provide the only expeditionary mine interdiction capability in the US Navy.  If these forces are not properly outfitted lives may be lost, access to sea lanes of communication could be severed, and risk to transiting forces will be elevated.   Specifically, upgrade kits to MK 18 Family of Systems will be procured to provide increased MCM capability;  MK 19 upgrade kits will be procured to provide EOD Response ROV capability for mine/unexploded ordinance (UXO) target prosecution; improved diver sensor tools will be procured to provide enhanced target detection and localization capabilities; and auxiliary equipment procured that is required to fully outfit systems to perform their intended missions.

OCO: 
$3.4M of FY 2018 Overseas Contingency Operations (OCO) will procure for two Mk 18 Mod 2 systems, critical equipment needed to outfit deploying NECC forces in support of ongoing USN operations in CENTCOM. Four MK 18 vehicles have been continuously deployed in theater for the last four years to support a critical capability in the Counter Mine mission. These operational prototype systems were developed, procured, and fielded in response to urgent operational needs.  To date, they have over 5000 operating hours and due to the extremely high OPTEMPO, these prototypes vehicles have experienced extensive wear and tear. As a result, these systems now require complete restoration and equipment replacement to return them to full operational status. 

$4.9M of FY 2018 OCO funding for Naval Special Warfare (NSW) will support the replacement of the Mk 18 Mod 1 unmanned undersea vehicle variant that US Navy SEALs currently employ as an intelligence collection platform  prior to conducting clandestine operations in support of Operation Inherent Resolve and other missions. These systems are critical to NSW's undersea component, mission planning for anti-access and area denial (A2AD) environments, and the current fight against violent extremist organizations.

$4.0M of FY 2018 European Reassurance Initiative (ERI) OCO funding will procure ExMCM equipment to provide significant improvements to Expeditionary MCM capability in the US SIXTH FLEET AoR.  This budget supports projects under the President's European Reassurance Initiative (ERI) to reassure allies of the U.S. commitment to their security and territorial integrity as members of the NATO Alliance, provide near-term flexibility and responsiveness to the evolving concerns of our allies and partners in Europe, especially Central and Eastern Europe, and help increase the capability and readiness of U.S. allies and partners.

Name.@footnote: CE 1.1.1 MIW-VIP: FY2018 efforts will focus on ranging RHIBS and unmanned systems to determine specific signature characteristics that will aid in development of tactics and procedures to ensure survivability of these systems in various operation conditions. MIW-VIP measures magnetic and acoustic signatures using existing ranges and portable ranges (Forward Area Combined Degaussing and Acoustic Range (FACDAR)).  Measurements are taken in both home port areas and deployment areas to assess susceptibility to various threat mines. Efforts across the FYDP include ranging RHIBS, newly acquired equipment (related OPNAV approved Table of Allowance items) and unmanned systems (i.e. MK 18 Mod's 1 & 2).

CE 2.1.2 MK 18 MOD 1 UMCM UUV INCREMENTAL (CIP) Retrofit Kit: Unit cost of individual retrofit kits may vary based on the number and type of technologies included and systems being upgraded and are identified as incremental Block Upgrades (e.g., current increment Block C retrofit kit is an upgrade in capability for the Mk 18 Mod 1 UUV system). These retrofit kits address more than one upgrade and address different functional area, i.e. enhanced navigation, system autonomy, improved post mission analysis, etc. Accordingly the number of retrofit kits may exceed number of systems/vehicles fielded
Name.val: 2.1.2) MK 18 MOD 1 UMCM UUV INCREMENTAL (CIP) Retrofit Kit

Name.@footnote: CE 2.1.3 MK 18 MOD 2 UUV: Provides for procurement of UUV MK 18 Mod 2 vehicles, which will be employed in operational missions in Shallow Water (SW) and Very Shallow Water (VSW) environments including rotational deployments to the Fifth Fleet and Seventh Fleet areas of responsibility.
CE 2.1.4 MK 18 Mod 2 Retrofit Kits (SSAM, ATLAS, Increment 1 and Increment 2): As of FY 17 this cost element has been further refined and defined  by cost elements 2.1.12, 2.1.13, 2.1.14, and 2.1.16.

CE 2.1.5 MK 18 MOD 2 RETROFIT KITS SYNTHETIC APERTURE SONAR (SSAM)- previously UMCM UUV INCREMENTAL (CIP) RETROFIT (BLKB):  Provides for procurement of UUV MK 18 Mod 2 retrofit kits, which will be employed in operational missions in Shallow Water (SW) and Very Shallow Water (VSW) environments including rotational deployments to the Fifth Fleet and Seventh Fleet area of responsibility. These retrofit kits add advanced capability to the MK 18 Mod 2 system. Unit costs of the advanced sensor retrofit kits can vary based on the number and type of sensor upgrades.

CE 2.1.6 MK 18 Mod 2 Retrofit Kits (ATLAS forward look sonar) - Previously UMCM UUV INCREMENTAL (CIP) RETROFIT (BLKD): Provides for procurement of UUV MK 18 Mod 2 retrofit kits, which will be employed in operational missions in Shallow Water (SW) and Very Shallow Water (VSW) environments including rotational deployments to the Fifth Fleet and Seventh Fleet area of responsibility. These retrofit kits add advanced capability to the MK 18 Mod 2 system. Unit costs of the advanced sensor retrofit kits can vary based on the number and type of sensor upgrades.

CE 2.1.7 MK 18 MOD 2 RETROFIT KITS INCREMENT 1(Autonomy and Automated Target Recognition):  Previously UMCM INCREMENT (CIP) (BLKC) - Provides for procurement of UUV MK 18 Mod 2 retrofit kits, which will be employed in operational missions in Shallow Water (SW) and Very Shallow Water (VSW) environments including rotational deployments to the Fifth Fleet and Seventh Fleet area of responsibility. These retrofit kits add advanced capability to the MK 18 Mod 2 system. Unit costs of the advanced sensor retrofit kits can vary based on the number and type of sensor upgrades.
CE 2.1.15 MK 18 MOD2 Overhaul: OCO funding will procure critical Mk 18 Mod 2 equipment needed to outfit deploying NECC forces in support of ongoing USN operations in CENTCOM.

CE 2.1.9 AUXILLIARY EQUIPMENT (MK 18 Family of Systems): Provides for procurement of OPNAV approved fleet outfitting of equipment other than UUVs that is required for the MK 18 and MK 19 systems to accomplish their missions. This includes equipment required for deployment, pre-mission planning and post mission analysis of the data collected by the UUVs. In addition, new procurement auxiliary kits will need to be procured to support enhancements to legacy fleet systems through engineering changes, system upgrades and obsolescence of legacy auxiliary kits.

CE 2.1.10 MK 19 FoS ROV Upgrades: Previously HULS Retrofit Kits - MK 19 FoS upgrades leverage advancements in robotic manipulators, target recognition software, user interface, and explosive recognition and neutralization that have been achieved in land robots and which can now be integrated into undersea remotely operated vehicles. These upgrades to previously fielded EOD response ROVs will enable more rapid reacquisition, identification and neutralization of mine like targets found by the MK 18 or other MCM search assets.
Name.val: 2.1.11) MK 19 FAMILY OF SYSTEMS ROV UPGRADES

Name.@footnote: CE 2.1.12 UW DIVER INTEGRATION SENSORS: Provides for the procurement of a family of systems based on Modified-Off-The Shelf (MOTS), mature technologies and upgrades to Diver Integrated Sensors. Unit cost of individual retrofit kits may vary based on number and type of technology included in the kit. FY 2018 funding addresses the obsolescence of the existing fleet inventory of the MK 15 Underwater Imaging System first fielded in 2004. This is the only sensor the EOD, Ex MCM and MDSU divers have to detect, locate and localize objects of interests including sea mines and underwater IEDs.

CE 2.1.13 ADVANCED FIRING SYSTEMS (AFS): FY 2018 will support the fielding of enhanced safety software for the fleet inventory of MK 58 Acoustic Firing Devices. This enhancement will specifically address the requirement for a diver safe-separation distance when placing the MK 58 AFD against an underwater explosive threat. The MK12 AFS is the only approved command detonation firing train the EOD and Ex MCM diver has in their toolbox. Outfitting of the latest product improvement will be completed with FY 18 resources.
CE 2.1.14 INFLUENCE SIGNATURE REDUCTION: Funding procures measurement and calibration equipment necessary to execute influence signature characterization and reduction projects.

CE 3.1.1. UNDERWATER (UW) INTEGRATED SYSTEM INTERFACE): FY2018 resources support the continued outfitting of the upgrade of COIN (Common Operator Interface, Navy, a graphical user interface) to interoperate with the MK 18 Family of Systems and the advanced sensors. COIN upgrades resourced in FY2017 will ensure interoperability with legacy MCM assets and that the fielding of the advanced sensors will meet interoperability performance requirements.

Name.val: UQ036 - DIVER SAFETY LIFE SUPPORT EQUIPMENT

Name.@footnote: CE 4.1.1 DIVER SAFETY LIFE SUPPORT EQUIPMENT: Provides for the procurement of a family of systems based on MOTS and mature technologies to provide safer tools and life support systems for EOD UMCM and MDSU operations.  Based on family of systems concept, unit cost of individual systems and sub-systems will vary based on number and type of technology included.

CE 5.1.1 MMS UMCM: Funding procures equipment needed to outfit MK 7 MMS detachments in support of Maritime Homeland Defense and contingency response MCM missions.  MK 7 MMS remains the only operational buried mine hunting capability in the US Navy.

CE 5.1.2 MMS ALLOWANCE: FY2018 funding supports outfitting of tools/equipment for all Fleet MMS in accordance with CNO approved allowance list. MK 7 MMS provides the USN's only buried mine hunting capability. Additionally, FY2018 funding will procure Medical Outfitting equipment required to meet statutory requirements.
CE 5.1.3 MEDICAL OUTFITTING: Provides funding to procure necessary medical equipment for Navy MMS in accordance with SECNAVINST 3900.41

Name.val: 5.1.4) UW LOW MAGNETIC TEST EQUIPM UPGRADE

Name.@footnote: CE 5.1.5 MMS LITTORAL PORT & HARBOR DEFENSE OPERATIONS: Funding procures equipment necessary for Fleet MMS to conduct port and harbor defense operations in support of USNORTHCOM Homeland Defense Contingency Response missions.
Name.val: 5.1.5) MMS LITTORAL PORT & HARBOR DEFENSE OPERATIONS

Name.@footnote: CE 6.1 Production Engineering: FY2018 funding supports the increased production of MK 18 and MK 19 Family of Systems requiring additional production support to include production contract award, first article tests, and factory acceptance tests.

CE 7.1 Product Improvement: Provides for engineering services to improve fielded MMS Systems/EOD Diver-based and unmanned systems to improve Human Systems Integration (HSI)/Logistics domains insert technology refresh and/or decrease costs.  FY 2018 resources in the PIP line will support increases in fleet inventories and the additional Engineering Change Proposals received based on lessons learned from extended fleet employment in the US fifth Fleet and the resultant expansion of mission applications.

CE 8.1 INITIAL TRAINING: FY 2018 funding provides resources needed due to the increase in training requirements due to expanded employment of fleet systems (i.e. mainly MK 18 and MK 19 Family of Systems) and increased inventory objectives. This training is required based on execution of acquisition programs, ECPs and product improvements.

Remarks.val: [Hardware/Recurring] CE 1.1) Ex MCM Outfitting: This funding resources the procurement of Expeditionary UUV-based systems and support equipment on the OPNAV approved Table of Allowance.  Procurement of this equipment will allow the UUV-based systems to be deployed globally and employed from a wide variety of shipboard platforms at sea as well as small craft.  ExMCM cost elements include MK 18 MOD 1 and Mod 2 UUVs which provides for procurement of UUV MK 18 vehicles, which will be employed in operational missions in Shallow Water (SW) and Very Shallow Water (VSW) environments including rotational deployments to the Fifth Fleet, Sixth Fleet, and Seventh Fleet areas of responsibility .Additional  ExMCM procurement cost elements include Open Water Transport Systems (OWTS), Shipboard Charging Containers (SCC), Auxiliary Equipment sets, Mission support Equipment, Maintenance Kits, and  Fleet Support Kits.   The various kits comprise the ancillary and support equipment necessary to outfit an  ExMCM Company with a complete set of Mk 18 UUV related equipment and are procured from a variety of OEMs and sources.

Name.@footnote: CE 1.1.1 Expeditionary MCM (EXMCM) MK 18 MOD 2UUV: This funding resources the procurement of Expeditionary UUV-based systems and support equipment on the OPNAV approved Table of Allowance.  Procurement of this equipment will allow the UUV-based systems to be deployed globally and employed from a wide variety of shipboard platforms at sea as well as small craft.
CE 1.1.2 ExMCM MK 18 MOD 2 Support Kit:Funding to procure the support kits (GETACs, PMA stations, etc) that comprise a portion of the Mk 18 Mod 2 system outfitting.
CE 1.1.3 ExMCM MK 18 MOD 2 Maint Kit: Funding to procure the maintenance kits (special tool kits, fly away maintenance modules, etc)that comprise a portion of the Mk 18 Mod 2 system outfitting
CE 1.1.8 ExMCM Mission Support Equipment (MSE): Funding to procure the mission support equipment (MILVANs, ESAMs, etc) that comprise a portion of the Mk 18 Mod 2 system outfitting
CE 1.1.9 ExMCM Procurement C6F OCO: OCO funding will procure critical ExMCM equipment needed to outfit deploying CTF 68 forces in support of ongoing USN operations in USSIXTHFLT AoR

Remarks.val: [Hardware/Recurring] MK 18 UUV outfitting in support of Naval Special Operation Forces.

Name.@footnote: CE:1.1.1 MK18 MOD1 UUV: FY18 OCO funding provides for the replacement procurement of (6) MK18 MOD1 UUV in support of contingency Naval Special Warfare missions. The MK18 UUV systems have been identified as a Navy service-common systems and beginning in FY18 are funded using Department of the Navy resources. Previous MK18 UUV systems were procured by Special Operations Command (SOCOM) funding.

CE:1.1.2 AUXILIARY EQUIPMENT (MK 18 MOD 1) FY18 OCO funding provided to Naval Special Warfare for procurement of equipment other than UUVs that is required for the MK18 to accomplish NSW missions.  This includes equipment required for deployment, pre-mission planning and post mission analysis of the data collected by the UUVs.

CE:1.1.3 MK18 MOD 1 Support Kits: FY18 OCO funding is provided to Naval Special Warfare for procurement of equipment other than UUVs that is required for the MK 18 MOD 1 systems to accomplish NSW missions. This includes On Board Repair Parts (OBRP)and other support equipment as required.
